docs.lead_paragraph: Congress voted on Friday to put 760,000 Federal workers back on the payroll for three weeks and to resume politically visible Government operations, from the national parks and medical research to payments for veterans' pensions, through September, and President Clinton approved the temporary end of the shutdown just after midnight. Congress approved three bills returning workers to their jobs and reopening closed programs to varying degrees. The White House said early today that Mr. Clinton had signed legislation to finance certain Federal programs, to return furloughed Federal employees to work at full pay and to reinstate pay for those employees who remained at their jobs.

headline.kicker: CONGRESS VOTES TO RETURN 760,000 TO FEDERAL PAYROLL AND RESUME SOMESERVICES

docs.lead_paragraph: A yearlong study of a dozen leading health maintenance organizations serving the New York City area found that their quality and generosity vary widely and that company representatives frequently give wrong information over the phone. The report, compiled by the office of Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate, said that the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, or H.I.P., the only nonprofit H.M.O. in the survey, had the greatest number of valid complaints from patients. Half of the 1,131 complaints filed between 1992 and 1994 were upheld by the Departments of Insurance and Health, the state agencies responsible for investigating them.

headline.main: Public Advocate Report Says H.M.O.'s Vary Widely in Quality andBenefits

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki today urged a Legislature that is wary about spending cuts in an election year to back the austerity budget that he sent it last month, promising lawmakers that the state would flourish under his proposals to reduce government. Mr. Pataki used his second annual address to the Legislature to drum up support for his $63.8 billion budget, a plan that calls for some of the deepest spending cuts in New York in recent decades.

headline.main: Pataki Says Backing Spending Cuts Will Help State Thrive

docs.lead_paragraph: It used to be that 9-year-old Rodney Palacios could not be still for more than a minute. At home, he would fiddle with the VCR, pressing the fast-forward and rewind buttons, but never actually sit through a movie. At school, he was frequently jumping out of his chair and defying his teachers. "He was unruly," said his father, Rodney Palacios Sr. "He didn't want to listen. He would go into the playground without the teacher's approval. He thought he was the boss."

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from Gov. George E. Pataki's State of the State Message yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times. . . . It's been a spectacular year. It's been an historic year, a year full of accomplishments for the people. We can be proud because we have made life better for New Yorkers -- after all, that is our purpose. For the first time in over a decade this government stands as the servant of the people and not the other way around. This is what New Yorkers want their government to be and we have heard them.

docs.lead_paragraph: If the Federal Government is to do less, then the private sector will have to do more. But AT&T's stunning announcement on the first business day of 1996 that it would permanently lay off 40,000 employees raises profound questions about the private sector's ability to take on more responsibility for Americans' economic well-being. I do not mean to pick on AT&T. It is but one in a long list of companies that have delivered large numbers of pink slips in recent years, despite record profits. Wall Street's initially positive response to AT&T's announcement suggests that the company may have done exactly the right thing by its shareholders. But this is precisely the issue. Do companies have obligations beyond the bottom line?

docs.lead_paragraph: Most of the time, the people who write the laws for the most populous county in the Pacific Northwest talk about tax increments and zoning variances. But for a few days over the last year, those people, the King County Council, have been rhapsodizing about garlic pills and the healing power of ginkgo tree extract. In voting to establish the nation's first government-subsidized natural medicine clinic, the Republican-dominated council sounded like a therapy group discussing wonder cures. One member said he owed his good health to a dietary supplement of enzymes and vitamins. Another said acupuncture cured her of migraine headaches. A third member said she used botanical fluid to help her relax.

headline.main: Seattle Area Giving Natural Medicine A Chance to Come In From theFringe

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City's labor unions are on a collision course with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over the issue they have made their No. 1 legislative priority: enacting a law that would require companies with city contracts to pay more than the $4.25-an-hour minimum wage. A coalition of 97 labor unions is pushing the City Council to approve one of two similar bills that would obligate city contractors to pay workers at least $9 an hour and provide health insurance.

headline.main: Unions Push for Higher Minimum Wage on New York City Contracts

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST year presented the vision. Is this one about to produce the reality? As Congressional Republicans move into their second year in power, their campaign to hack away at mounds of Government regulations is likely to have its first tangible impact on business -- from Wall Street to Hollywood, from silicon to steel.

headline.main: Giving Business A Chance to Test The Wings of Deregulation

docs.lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton had been ceding ground and seeking compromise for months, by temperament always the conciliator. But one day in early November, the President spelled out the limits of accommodation. Closeted in the Oval Office with the leaders of Congress, Mr. Clinton told the Republicans that he would give them much of their budget, aides said. To win everything, the President said, pointing at the dark oak antique that Queen Victoria gave to Rutherford B. Hayes, they would have to elect someone else to sit at that desk.

headline.main: Clinton the Conciliator Finds His Line in Sand
